entries.label: Core Numeracy Skills

policy.assessment_notes: Focus on mental maths and written methods for the four operations.

entries.notes: Begin with the Numeracy unit to build a strong foundation as recommended by SQA. This lesson ensures learners have the core skills needed for subsequent units.

entries.label: Numeracy Skills Check

policy.assessment_notes: Short, low-stakes quiz based on SQA assessment stems. Allows for both non-calc and calc questions to assess appropriate tool use.

entries.notes: Early formative assessment to identify and address any gaps in fundamental numeracy before moving to more complex applications.

entries.label: Perimeter & Area

coherence.unit: Applications of Mathematics: Shape, Space and Measures (National 3)

policy.assessment_notes: Calculations will involve measurements in context, making calculator use appropriate.

entries.notes: Moving to the Shape, Space and Measures unit. Using authentic contexts like garden design helps make the concepts of perimeter and area tangible.

entries.label: Time Calculations

coherence.unit: Applications of Mathematics: Shape, Space and Measures (National 3)

policy.assessment_notes: Contextual problems involving timetables where a calculator would be a realistic tool.

entries.notes: Practice-focused lesson using real Scottish timetables (e.g., First Bus, ScotRail) to build confidence with time intervals and 24-hour clock.

entries.label: Shape, Space & Measures Unit Assessment

coherence.unit: Applications of Mathematics: Shape, Space and Measures (National 3)

policy.assessment_notes: A mock assessment covering all outcomes for the unit, modelled on the official SQA Unit Assessment Support Pack.

entries.notes: This mock assessment provides a formal opportunity to gauge readiness for the real internal unit assessment.

entries.label: Income & Budgeting

coherence.unit: Applications of Mathematics: Manage Money and Data (National 3)

policy.assessment_notes: Budgeting involves multiple calculations where a calculator is essential.

entries.notes: Introducing the final unit, Manage Money and Data. This lesson uses relatable scenarios like a teenager's first job to teach budgeting.

entries.label: Best Buys Project

coherence.unit: Applications of Mathematics: Manage Money and Data (National 3)

policy.assessment_notes: Project-based learning where students compare real products. Calculator is necessary.

entries.notes: A project-based lesson where students use real flyers from Scottish supermarkets (Lidl, Aldi) to find the best deals, applying percentage and fraction skills in a practical context.

entries.label: Organising & Presenting Data

coherence.unit: Applications of Mathematics: Manage Money and Data (National 3)

policy.assessment_notes: Creating graphs may not require a calculator, but interpreting data to find totals or averages will.

entries.notes: This lesson covers the data handling aspect of the unit, focusing on creating and interpreting simple charts like bar graphs from relatable data sets.

accessibility_notes: The course materials are designed to be dyslexia-friendly, using sans-serif fonts and clear layouts. Practical, hands-on activities with concrete materials are encouraged to support diverse learners. Multi-step problems will be broken down into smaller, manageable steps.
